39723622.review:
Port of Call es uno de esos Free to Plays de Steam que realmente desconoces si es bueno o malo. Conozco gente que por el mero hecho de que sea gratis ya desconfían, ya sea porque probablemente sea un PayToWin, o porque sea un mojón. De esto tengo que decir que es ninguna de las dos opciones.

Como catalogarlo es algo complicado ya que tiene un poco de todo. Su principal aspecto es la atmósfera, alimentada por el desconocimiento. El no saber qué, cómo ni por qué le da al pequeño escenario algo de misterio, y el sentirte encerrado. También una pizca de terror, ya que hay situaciones y/o sonidos que son bastante espeluznantes, además de que cuando te vas dando cuenta de la historia se va tornando bastante creepy el asunto. También se le podría catalogar como Point and Click o Aventura Gráfica, pero al final esto es como una receta de cocina. Realizas un escenario con buena atmósfera y vas añadiendo pequeños ingredientes a la mezcla. Una buena mezcla

El aspecto gráfico es lo que probablemente haya echado a más gente atrás. Al fin y al cabo, no es nada más que un pequeño escenario con solo y exclusivamente polígonos 3D con texturas. No hay modelado ni biselado, ni bordes suavizados. Pero al final estamos hablando de algo opcional (Excepto para algunas personas)

La ambientación sonora es bastante buena. Juegos con una canción o melodía sonando durante todo el rato se hace bastante cansado y repetitivo. Solución, poner música en momentos clave. Momentos tristes o misteriosos, y les quedó muy bien. Los efectos de sonido no estoy seguro si son de esos de libre uso, pero viendo que en algunas partes del juego se dicen algunas palabras, incluyendo el final, le da bastante originalidad.

Los logros acompañan muy bien al juego. No son muchos, para no estresar al jugador, pero tampoco escasos, como los típicos pásate el juego y punto. Si eres una persona curiosa, es bastante probable que los hayas conseguido todos menos uno de una tirada. Pero si no es así, no te preocupes. 3 se consiguen durante el transcurso normal del mismo, 2 requieren un poco de exploración y curiosidad, y los otros 2 son los dos finales distintos. Una vez consigues un final el juego te invita a completarlo otra vez, dándote cuenta de más detalles y así ver el juego con otros ojos al saber ya el transfondo. Esto es buen diseño de guión, señores.

No tengo mucho más que decir sin hacer spoilers. Realmente lo recomiendo y no toma más de una hora completarlo. Es intuitivo y muy bueno, y la verdad es que me encantaría ver Port of Call en HD, sería un juegazo por el cual pagaría. De lo mejor que he jugado en este 2018.

36209828.review:
This is a charming little free game that will take maybe 30 mins to complete (if you read through every bit of dialogue, which is worthwhile imo), and another 5-10 minutes to complete all achievements due to 2 choices at the end of the story.  There are also a couple of guides that are accurate, in case someone is stuck or wants a faster 100% achi.

Symbolism, minimalism, and melancholy are all appropriate descriptors for this short adventure, and I was surprised at the effectiveness of such minimlalistic dialogue to convey the same feeling as one might experience after realizing that a long-ago heartbreak had finally become a part of the mosaic of one's past, rather than an everyday burden.

Regarding the ending, it's one of those in which there is a sense of both completion and closure.

Appropriate for all ages, though the nuance of the story will not likely be appreciated by very young players.

For what it is (free, short story, low budget), I rate this product 8/10 - very nice job, Underdog Games!

34797978.review:
"Port of Call" is a very short experience (30-60 min.), so I won't risk spoiling any details by describing the plot. Suffice it to say that the game has an intriguing premise and an interesting story that kept my interest throughout (even though, like other reviewers have mentioned, the twists are fairly easy to guess). 

There's no action, you simply wander around talking to people and solving light puzzles. The graphic are very primitive and simplistic, but somehow it only adds to the style and strangeness of the game. Speaking of which, the atmosphere is where "Port of Call" really shines: the world the game creates is oddly immersive, beautiful and haunting - which is especially impressive considering the low production values, near-lack of voice acting and minimalistic sound design. The overall vibe is surreal and eerie, with occasional hints of creepiness.

So to conclude, "Port of Call" is a lovely little free-to-play game that is more than the sum of its parts. Recommend to anyone who doesn't mind a slower-paced, more contemplative, story-driven experience.

Final Verdict: 7.0 out of 10

34442899.review:
Port of Call is a game I didn't have much interest in, but one of my friends asked me to play and review. I found it for free on the Steam store and decided to just give it a go. It didn't seem like it was going to be a long game, and the achievements all seemed relatively easy to pick up.

I loaded the game up, went to play it and found myself pretty bored quickly. I didn't go about it correctly so I just closed it after popping one of the first achievements on the game and then didn't come back to it for a day or so. After finally finding a walk through that told me I had to talk to the Captain of the ship when you first go onto it, I reopened the game and went about it.

What I found was an incredibly well thought and well plotted out short story. This game really made me think a lot about things that most people don't think about. When the game finished, I was left just blinking at my screen, digesting what had just happened. I was left wanting more from this game, wanting to discover even more about the characters in the game, but unfortunately, this game is pretty open and shut within itself, so there really isn't anything more they could do to expand on this universe.

One thing I did find rather aggravating was the fact I had to go through the whole game twice to get the two achievements at the end - there's no saving mechanism - but this makes the Loot achievements much easier to get. Even though it was a really quick game to get through (it only took me under half an hour to go through it twice and pick all the achievements up) this was still relatively annoying, especially if you're pressed for time.

The only problem I had with this game as a whole, however, was how it seemed quite laggy and it would jump around a little bit. This game really should have run much smoother than it did on my laptop, and the little jumps in the environment and constant lag when my character moved just really got on my nerves. That is something that really needs to be fixed because boy oh boy does that get annoying quickly.

Other than these two things, this game is really enjoyable, really thought-provoking, and I would definitely recommend this to everyone! Gamers and achievement hunters alike!

33618122.review:
[h1]Port of Call is an interesting and charming game that spoils itself.[/h1]


This game has potential. The way it is now, it feels a lot like a piece of a game. The story is interesting, but I figured out what the twist would be on the second passenger, when you aren't supposed to find out until the end of the story. I'll explain in more detail in the paragraph below, spoilers aplenty. It's also very short, and not in a "it's a short story" sort of way, it felt rushed, like it had a lot more story to tell than time and parts had been cut out. It's not a bad game or anything, and I feel like you can't complain about a free game anyway. I enjoyed it for what it was, a quick story with enjoyable characters and well written dialogue. You can't really go wrong with a free game. Unless it's [i]Let the Cat In[/i].


Here's a more detailed explanation of how Port of Call spoils itself.

[spoiler]There are two main twists in Port of Call, one is that everyone is dead and this is a boat to the afterlife, and the other is the identity of the player character. The first twist isn't much of a twist, it's very obvious from the beginning what's going on but the game drags it out as a big reveal at the end. Now onto the second twist. The first passenger you speak to, Lily, explains that she died while playing hide and seek with her brother, Marcus. The second passenger, Horace, says his daughter had died and he was left with his son. Hmm, I sure do wonder if these two are related. As Horace...disappears in a blinding flash of light? I don't know, it makes more sense while playing. As he does that, he says something like "Thanks Marcus" and there goes the plot. You're Marcus, that's the end of the story. But the dang character doesn't seem to have the smarts to think his way out of a paper bag though, so he doesn't have a clue. He then goes to talk with the third character, Alice. She drones on and on about how she's looking for someone but doesn't know who, alludes to Marcus, yeah yeah whatever. Onto the boilerman, who makes it sound like some amazing and dramatic twist that WOW everyone is DEAD and the people you met are your FAMILY and you're MARCUS but in reality you already knew this, you knew everyone was dead before you even got past the title screen, let's be honest. If the twist was hidden better I would have liked this a lot more. It's got charm to it, but I couldn't correctly enjoy the story it was trying to tell. And I never want to talk about the Lavender Crayon again.[/spoiler]

33421928.review:
Port of Call is a very short free-to-play adventure game spanning only about half an hour for a single playthrough.  The controls are very simplistic and standard for a first-person game so it is very simple to jump into the game without having to learn an obscure interface or control scheme.  Despite its short length, the game comes with some replayablility with two possible endings as well as seven Steam Achievements to collect.  However, these achievements can be obtained in no more than two playthroughs creating little incentive to play the game again after getting all the achievements and both endings.  I still do, however, highly recommend the game as due to the short nature of a playthrough it is an excellent game to show a friend.

The game opens rather abruptly to the player character on a dock in the middle of nowhere and a mysterious ghostly woman looking out into the endless ocean.  The player has no memory of how he arrived at this place or who he even is. Upon turning around, the woman vanishes and the player is being told to board a ship by a strange ferryman.  Turning around again, the ship suddenly appears and can be boarded and the game begins.  The player must discover who he is and why he is on the ferryboat, completing tasks given to him by the ferryman.

The story itself is very simple and, at times, predictable, and though the player has options during dialogue sequences, these choices affect nothing in the game, but add a sense of choice for the player.  Are you a horrible person? A sympathetic person? Do you want to make the little girl cry, or comfort her? It gives an artificial feeling of having an impact on the world in the game, and this is not a bad thing. It can give the player the feeling of wanting to play again, perhaps, and make different choices.  Be the good guy in one playthrough, and the bad guy in the next.  There is a level of satisfaction regardless of whether the choice has any real impact on the game or not.

The first thing the player will notice about the game is the clearly stylised design. The graphics are incredibly simplistic, though unique enough to be charming.  The characters in the game (save for the ferryman and the player) wear strange masks that distort their faces.  Not only is this a style purposely chosen for the game, but it does play a part in the story.  The minimalism can turn off some players because there are little to no textures on objects, the colour palette is rather dull, and the characters are a bit ugly.  However, the drab nature of the design builds the bleak atmosphere the game intended on having.  Though some of the design choices can be seen as lazy, they can just as easily be seen as artistic choices intentionally made to fit a style.  Given that this game is free, the art design works for what it is.

Lastly, the music is superb, a bit too good for a free game.  It’s slow, bleak, and feels like a sad shanty.  The full game soundtrack is available, and I recommend it.  The mood it creates is perfect.  The music makes the player feel like a slow, dark, sad ferryboat is going through a slow, dark, sad ocean for a dark and sad purpose.

The game succeeds in being what it intended to be, and it was good enough I would have paid money to play it.

31479636.review:
[b] Minor plot details ahead, but no spoilers. It may be better to go in blind, but everything I describe you will learn in the opening minute or so. [/b]

Port of Call is a short, free walking simulator that presents a nice story about death, and learning to accept it. It's nice atmosphere and short story offer a fun, if not somewhat dark, time. Basically, you start on a dock, then head to a ship, and collect tickets for the ferryman. There are four people with a ticket, each with their own story to tell. As time passes, you start to unravel the story and realize that there is more going on than meets the eye. From a technical standpoint, this game works great. Graphics are minimal, but the hard edges and color pallate make for some nice looking level design. I was also impressed with some instant loading times and a small physics engine. I also didn't encounter any glitches. Overall, this was a fun game, and I think everyone should give it a try. It's short, free, and there are seven super easy achivements to help get you a 100% completed game, which is neat. Give it a try, and see for yourself.

Spoilers: [spoiler] So basically you are in Limbo, between life and death. The people who you need to collect tickets from are your sister (died tragically), father (drunkard), wife (died of broken heart, like Padme apparently), and yourself (guilt manifested as an alternate "you"). The story is basically you recalling these events by having the respective people tell you about it. Then, the boat docks and you are left with a choice. Submit to death, and live with your wife in Heaven, or resist death, and return to the land of the living. There are two portals you can walk through in order to choose. If you choose death, you hear your wife calling out to you, as if you are joining her in love again. If you choose life, you hear a hospital, as if you almost died but came back. Port of Call is a simple game, but fun nonetheless. If you have a few minutes to spare and want to try something new, try this. Trust me, it's worth your time. [/spoiler]

30401797.review:
The short length, pitiful graphics and merely-adequate sound can all be overlooked if the story is interesting.  After all, it's a free game.  Tell a powerful story, and all else will be forgiven.

Unfortunately, [i]Port of Call[/i]'s story isn't good, either.  Yes, there are elements here that you've seen in better, more compelling tales, but that's exactly the problem.  You've seen these twists and revelations before, and they're not being used in a novel or inventive way here.  Before you've even boarded the ship you should already have discerned one of the game's big upcoming revelations.  Talking to just the first passenger should make the other big surprise obvious -- one that you're not supposed to realize until several passengers later.  I'm speaking vaguely to avoid spoilers here, but the issue is that the game spoils itself.  With the game's mysteries laid bare far before they were intended to be, you're left in a clumsily-made environment, running through dialogue trees where your choices change nothing, just so that your character can realize things that were obvious to you ten minutes earlier.

Finally, you reach the end, where you must make the most dramatic and important choice of all.  And it, too, functionally changes nothing, since the diametrically opposed endings still feel almost identical.  And if you want all the Achievements, you'll know this, since you have to experience them both.

A tremendous story can make technical weaknesses unimportant.  Amazing graphics and sound can make a clichéd story still feel intense.  [i]Port of Call[/i] has neither.

Basicamente,no início há confusão, pois seu personagem não tem idéia de por que ele está no navio - nem por que o misterioso capitão de bigode o tem preso a bordo. À medida que aprofundava o mistério do porquê de estar naquele navio estranho e conheci seus poucos habitantes igualmente desconcertantes, comecei a entender que todos compartilhavam o que parecia ser uma morte trágica. A busca do significado por trás disso (e por que você está aqui com eles) é o que impulsiona sua aventura.

Enquanto me movia de cômodo para quarto, investigava o ventre do navio: pinturas abstratas pendem em lugares estranhos nas paredes, e algumas cabines não têm gravidade; Livros flutuam desta forma e que, e móveis fica nas paredes. Um deles contém a mesa de um escritor, com o papel amassado arremessado e os rascunhos descartados espalhados pelo chão da sala - em outro, um baú de brinquedo de criança que é desproporcionalmente imponente e grande. Todas essas coisas são simbólicas para os diferentes personagens de maneiras que são reveladas quanto mais você mergulhar na história.

O estilo da arte abstrata não é restringido simplesmente às pinturas. Os rostos das pessoas que você conhece têm características misturadas com linhas e formas vagas, como se você não pudesse juntar o que eles realmente pareciam. Estes elementos se combinam para dar um único e interessante, quase ... etéreo sentir toda a experiência.

船长让主角去收集乘客们的票，在此过程中主角发现船上的每个人都已经死了，而他却不确定自己的死活。和三位乘客的对话中有一个名字，马库斯，而哭泣的女子提到了电梯有时会通向楼下，带着各种谜团乘坐电梯向下，在那里看到了那个戴着面具的神秘人，谜底一一揭晓，原来主角就是马库斯，而三位乘客，依次是他的妹妹，父亲和妻子，神秘人是主角的消极人格的具象化。母亲病逝，妹妹因为自己的一时疏忽死去，父亲整日饮酒，妻子也在等待中离开人世。
最后，在灯塔前，是选择两扇门，一扇，是找到了归宿，另一扇，是继续流浪，一切未知。

[i] “The destination is but an incidental consequence of the journey.” [/i]

Port of Call is a narrative exploration game developed and published by the company Underdog Games.

[i] Pro & contra: [/i]

+ Immersive short-form storytelling. 

o Occasional use of musical background and sounds.  

- Low quality graphics with some questionable elements.

[i] Summary: [/i]

Recommended for achievement hunters and curious explorers.

Multiplayer achievements: none

Port Of Call is a fairly decent indie adventure game. If you're looking for a horror game, which this is tagged as, I'm afraid you will be disappointed. The atmosphere of the game is alright, although while mysterious it is not creepy or scary in any way. The game's graphics are very simplistic although okay for a F2P indie game. 
The story of the game is very original and interesting, however the gameplay time is only approximately 30 minutes and consists mainly of conversations without voice over. 

If you're looking for an interesting and original, however short, indie game, this is just the game you're looking for. If you however want to be a little creeped out even, this might not be the game you want to play.

If you're interested, you can find my full playthrough here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_FC3U3rkOBg

26238478.review:
[table][tr][td][url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/MentorPixel]Mentor Píxel[/url] - [i]Análisis bit a bit[/i][/td][/tr][/table]

[i]Port of Call[/i] se presenta como un juego gratuito de corta durabilidad, con la premisa de ser un experimento que explora el aspecto inmersivo del medio, encargado de ubicar argumentalmente al jugador en una trama sin introducción, —pues el título da inicio dentro del marco jugabilístico y no mediante cinemáticas o textos— por lo que uno debe buscar la trama mediante la interacción desde el vamos.

Visualmente el juego no resulta ostentoso, más sí atmosférico. Dicha atmósfera logra crear una conexión entre el jugador y el protagonista en su búsqueda de respuestas, logrando una unión natural entre escenarios y personajes. Todo eso de la mano de un escenario pequeño, que intenta no colocar lugares de más en pos de no distraer al jugador.

[h1]Argumento[/h1]
En un muelle vacío, apartado de toda costa —mas no de un faro en la lejanía— se divisa bajo el manto nocturno de estrellas una figura femenina que se desvanece como si de un espejismo se tratase, dando pie a un viejo a nuestras espaldas que nos recibe, dándonos a entender que aguardaba nuestra llegada, este personaje resulta ser el capitán del barco que tenemos a nuestras espaldas, materializado ahora como si de un navío fantasma se tratase. Embarcados y dejando el muelle detrás, el capitán parece conocernos más que nosotros mismos, pues todo lo que sabemos es lo que pasó desde el momento en el que pisamos el muelle, como si nos hubiésemos originado allí, en ese preciso instante.

Sin ningún conocimiento, deberemos recorrer los pasillos de la depresiva nave, rodeada de una ominosa atmósfera, en donde se divisan vacíos páramos marinos sin el menor rastro de tierra a la vista, surcando mar abierto en dirección al lejano faro, mientras a su vez, se nos cruza por los pasillos aquella figura femenina que en un principio se había manifestado. 

Como pide el capitán, deberemos serle de ayuda y pedir los boletos de ciertos integrantes de la tripulación, pero para lograr eso, deberemos mantener una charla con ellos antes de que se dignen a otorgarnos dicho papel. A medida que se conozca a cada tripulante, la trama comenzará a moldearse frente a nuestros ojos y, con ella, comprenderemos quienes somos, y cómo acabamos allí.

No es en sí la historia lo que se aprecia de este título, sino como esta es contada, a través de los individuos con quienes entremos en contacto. Mecánicamente el juego permite moldear los diálogos, leyendo y preguntando. Es así como se nos proporcionará de variadas preguntas a las cuales nuestros receptores responderán; dicha mecánica no está ahí para cambiar sustancialmente la trama, sino que sirve como medio narrativo; es por esto que el juego se basa en la historia, manifestada a través de conversaciones en las cuales, al poder interactuar en pos de recibir diferentes diálogos, entra el factor inmersivo, pues no solo seremos espectadores, sino también participantes. Dicho sistema de interacción resulta básico a la manera que fue implementada, pero para este título de corta duración, bastó y sobró para entregar una experiencia satisfactoria.

[h1]Controles/Interfaz[/h1]
Al iniciar el juego podremos elegir su calidad, resolución, entre ejecutarlo en modo ventana o pantalla completa, y, sobre todo, personalizar las teclas designadas. En el menú principal solo podremos iniciar la aventura, no sin antes ser abordados por una imagen explicando los controles de interacción. No posee interfaz, pues no hay nada que la justifique en este caso, dado que el título se inclina a la inmersión del jugador.

[h1]Jugabilidad[/h1]
Al ser un walking simulator no posee particularidades de maniobrabilidad o interacción en cuanto a su faceta jugable, pues este título se enfoca a la experiencia, dejando de lado la jugabilidad, reduciéndola a lo más simplista e intuitiva que pueda llegar a ser.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]
A pesar de su simpleza, este título logra su cometido, otorgando una historia con un grado de inmersión apropiado para su duración, y es que esta misma resulta justificada a fin de cuentas, tomando en cuenta la trama que se desarrolla, el lugar de la misma y siendo este un juego gratuito. No dudaría en pagar si se desarrolla un poco más de cara a futuro.

26178068.review:
Ci sono giochi che emozionano particolarmente per il loro gameplay, per la loro storia, per il loro comparto sonoro, per la loro profonfità del combat system... e poi,circa la metà della metà della metà della metà di tutti i giochi in circolazione, che emoziona per la loro ambientazione e per la loro grande capacità di immedesimare il giocatore negli avvenimenti a schermo. Port of Call è uno di questi giochi.


Attenzione, Port of Call non è assolutamente un titolo ottimo o in qualsiasi caso un must have, e forse non è neanche un titolo da tenere d'occhio, è un titolo solamente buono,sufficiente,niente di più,niente di meno. Ma è una sufficienza vera, acquisita poichè meritata, ed è una sufficienza che la si sente quando si prova il titolo. Ovviamente ne parlo con un accezione positiva.

Port of Call è prima di tutto un'esperienza, un miscuglio di emozioni confuse che poi convergono tutte alla fine del gioco dove viene risolto l'enigma dell'avventura. Port of Call è un titolo che va giocato tutto d'un fiato, non ci sono salvataggi e questa è una scelta di game design molto azzeccata sopratutto per ciò che la produzione propone. Parlando di durata del titolo, sarà sufficiente una sessione di 40/50 minuti per portare al termine l'avventura. Una sessione di circa 2 ore per portarla al termine con ambe due i finali. 

Port of Call è un'avventura grafica di tutto rispetto che usa l'ambientazione e la buona caratterizzazione (in termine di background narrativo, non di tecnica) dei personaggi per coinvolgere il giocatore. E ci riesce, cavolo se ci riesce. Port of Call ha una sola ambientazione, una nave. Ed è tutta una metafora per esprimere un concetto molto ampio che il giocatore andrà ad identificare nel suo vissuto. La storia non è niente di che se presa come storia a sè stante, ma se presa come uno spunto di riflessione è di una profondità disarmante per un titolo indie, venduto poi anche gratis. La storia procede velocemente e senza tanti colpi di scena, quei pochi che ci sono risultano essere telefonati e sono clichè del genere, niente di eccezionale insomma. Ma quello che colpisce è la capacità del gioco di coinvelgere semplicemente con l'ambientazione, è la capacità di far vivere il titolo in noi, è la capacità che ha di far pensare al titolo anche ad avventura conclusa, sono stato tanto tempo a pensare, a riflettere sugli avvenimenti e sul finale, di scelta davvero molto personale. I due finali sono molto semplici ad un primo impatto ma se presi seriamente davvero molto complessi e profondi.

Il gameplay praticamente non esiste, ma essendo un'avventura grafica non ne vedo la pecca. WASD per muoversi, Click Sinistro per intereagire, Movimento del Mouse per spostare la visuale. Basta.

Il comparto sonoro ci accompagna per tutta la misera(ma giustificata) durata del titolo con alcuni pezzi davvero molto azzeccati per l'ambientazione. I Characters Theme poi sono incredibilmente inseriti bene per ogni personaggio, e nel mentre siamo assopiti nella lettura dei dialoghi( non c'è doppiaggio) sembra quasi che la musica faccia da doppiatrice, davvero davvero alienante, ma in senso estremamente positivo. 

Insomma in toto è un'esperienza che oggettivamente è sufficiente ma soggettivamente è uno di quei titoli indie che non ti aspetti di giocare e di trovare, sopratutto a gratis. E' davvero un titolo molto complesso e profondo, ma molto semplice e banale e quasi mediocre se preso superficialmente. Vi consiglio di provarlo ma sarà la vostra persona a decretare un giudizio sul titolo, che nel mio caso è estremamente positivo. Appunto per questa grande disparità tra giudizio oggettivo e soggettivo, non mi sento di dare una valutazione fissa per il titolo, ma consiglio A TUTTI di provarlo, a qualcuno sortirà lo stesso effetto a me dato, ossia un inebriazione di sentimenti ed emozioni che sfociano in spunti di riflessioni davvero profondi.

25693020.review:
[h1]“We make choices. No one else can live our lives for us. And we must confront and accept the consequences of our actions.”[/h1] - Neil Gaiman, The Sandman

[b]Port of Call[/b] is a short point and clicker sort of adventure where you get to board a ship bound to nowhere and follow a strange grumpy Captain. Who you are, where you're going and why you're there becomes clear throughout the game.

[h1]I really loved this.[/h1] The graphics' simple, the gameplay is basic, the choices you make yield very linear results but the overall feel of the game is fantastic. It's pretty polished for a free to play game. It's enjoyable and the feels man. It's a sad story even if it's eerie. Tbh, walking through the shadows queue gave me goosebumps! But this is not a horror game.

So dont hesitate to try this one out. I highly recommended this game. I'd even pay for a remastered / upgraded version of this.

무료에다가 도전과제까지 있는 1시간 분량의 어드벤처 게임이다.
영문 게임이라 내용은 자세히 모르겠지만 잠시 즐기면서 도전과제 추가용으로 좋은 게임.

더 이상 설명이 필요없이 직접 한번 해보면 알것이다.

25013977.review:
加在前面的话：

必须承认接触这个游戏是出于“全成就好拿”的缘故，然而，这款流程不超过30分钟的小游戏营造的用心程度意外不错，其中的内涵倒不至于让你大彻大悟，只能算是，在这么一个独处的时间里，给你讲一个温馨的故事。玩游戏嘛 ~ 本来就是娱乐项目，无脑刷一下全成就二十分钟，好好感受一下故事也是二十分钟，都是个人选择嘛。

我只是想起了乔治·R·R·还不出第六部·马丁在《晨临雾逝》写道的那句话：“只有幽魂不见了。”

**************************
这是关于一个弥留之际的灵魂在亡者的船上一脸懵逼的被船长派去收票的故事。

很短的游戏，动画渲染的风格，空荡荡的船和几段对话。但氛围营造得当，线索清晰，伏笔埋的恰到好处，剧情饱满，几个一晃而过的人物也十分鲜活。如此简单的故事却让人印象深刻，何况还是免费游戏，感兴趣的话花个二十分钟体验一下真心不错。

忽然发现无论怎么写感想都会剧透的样子....

那么就不管不顾的剧透好啦。

这个故事的结构，非常像我以前看过的一本名为《你在天堂里遇见的五个人》，[spoiler]同样是讲一个灵魂在刚刚步入亡者的世界，与自己生命中一些重要的时刻遇到的人交流，对话，最终得以释开心结，放下悔恨和痛苦的故事。[/spoiler]

但对于我个人来说，我并不是特别喜欢那本书的表现方式，因为感觉起来太刻意了，五个灵魂动用五场幻境的大排场，纯粹是为了给主角疗伤，整个故事充满了仪式性和宗教感，感觉读着读着就和故事里的世界拉开了距离。

而在这款游戏中则没有这样的问题，三个人，一个不完整的灵魂，他们出现在那里，是散布着模糊阴影中，为数不多的可见形体（“只有你见过的人才能看清他们的样子”）。

[spoiler]女孩是为了再见一次哥哥的面，问问当时在干什么，为什么不来找自己。

中年大叔是为了和被自己冷落了的儿子再呆上一会，喝着儿子亲手调的酒完成最后的旅途，也算是把饮酒至死贯彻到底了。

年轻女子是为了再见一次爱人的面，即使他曾抛下自己（“在船上游荡的久了，连他长什么样子也都不记得了”）。

而那个看上去很不好惹的不完整的灵魂，则是为了等那个在悔恨、疼苦和遗憾中迷失自我的人前来，找到旅途的真正目的，找回自己另一半的真实。

即使他一直自责，怀疑，内疚，但他们真的没有怨恨过他啊。当人们生死两隔时，相见一面都显得无比珍贵。而他的自责、怀疑、内疚，这一切的负面情绪虽然曾经支配着他，让他忘记自己的名字，忘记自己要去地方，却意外成为和他逝去的亲人与爱人相联的锁链，引导着他，发现最后的真相。

哦对，还有那个船长，开始看他一本正经的样子，还真的以为这是一艘要往哪里开的船呢，搞半天，到最后也只是在自己一生的海面上闲逛啊。[/spoiler]

对于这种别致的游戏，缺点什么的都不重要啦，唯一的遗憾是船上摆着飘着那么多书，一本都不能读，真是憋死游戏内置书籍爱好者了。

This is a neat little free game but I had a few issues playing.  During the dialogue parts I found that sometimes it would skip over the next line, as if I'd double clicked fast when I was purposefully clicking slowly to avoid the issue.  It meant that on quite a few occasions I entered dialogue lines I wouldn't have chosen and didn't get to read .

Also, at the end I decided to take the left hand choice (trying not to give out spoilers here) and the screen just went white. I had no option to leave the game and no visuals or dialogue. I don't know if that's the point, given the choice in game or if that's a bit of a glitch as I didn't get rolling credits or end game dialogue come up. If this is the way the game has been designed then it maybe needs something there to show the player that the game is over.

Overall though it was a nice, quick little point and click with a predictable but interesting storyline and an eerie feel to the whole thing, especially the whispering room.  I'd recommend to waste 30 minutes with.

24799399.review:
"Port of Call" ist ein kostenloses, kurzes, storygetriebenes First-Person-Exploration Game.

Charon, der Fährmann der die Toten gegen einen Obulus über den Fluss Styx in den Hades bringt...
Mehr sei hier nicht gesagt. Die kurze, gut gebaute Geschichte sollte man selbst erleben. Es lohnt sich.   

Die wenigen Charaktere sind verschroben und merkwürdig, und dadurch richtig spannend. Die englischen Texte sind zwar einfach, aber treffend und intelligent gebaut.

Technisch ist das Ganze eher schwach, die Unity Grafik nicht gerade herausragend. Aber: die Atmosphäre stimmt, die Welt ist in sich schlüssig und stilsicher. Ebenso ist die Soundkulisse treffend und stimmungsvoll. 

Das Alles verschmilzt zu einer eigenen Welt mit einer gekonnten kleinen Geschichte, die uns anzugehen vermag. Beeindruckend anders und doch vertraut. Irritierend und gerade deswegen wahr.

Klare Zockempfehlung.

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
9/10 Atmosphäre
8/10 Story
7/10 Grafik
7/10 Sound
7/10 Spielmechanik
-/10 Balancing
8/10 Spielspass

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Für diese kleine kostenlose Überfahrt sollte man dringend ein Ticket lösen. Unbedingt erleben!

[h1][b]8/10 Gesamtwertung

24178305.review:
Good:

- The atmosphere was neat.  It was effectively moody and there were a few things in the beginning that made me jump.

Bad:

- (Spoilers) I was able to figure out the story in the first five minutes.  In the end, the story is just given to you through a monologue from a character that was just a bit too creatively pretentious.  In the end I'm not entirely sure what the point of it all was.  What did the character learn?  His identity?  Based on the choice in the end he was going to learn either way who he was.

On that note, it seemed like everything was being built up to reveal that the main character had in fact done something horrible, but in the end, it's just revealed that you didn't... I guess.  As in, you remained passive your entire life.  And in the end you get to finally make a choice.  A choice that seemed mostly arbitrary and useless, because he either gets everything he wants, or... he doesn't.  For no reason.  Was it entirely necessary to make him forget who he was for thirty minutes just to make that choice?

tl;dr - Solid atmosphere but the story was a bit too pointless and pretentious for my taste.

24025468.review:
“Кэрол Энн, не иди на свет!”

Знаете иногда полезно поискать среди бесплатных инди-игр - “не хорроры” и не казуальную мазню, для того чтобы посмотреть как в этот раз будет выворачиваться разработчик при отсутствии денег/времени/технологий/скилла (нужное подчеркнуть).

Именно такой игрой стала Port of call без графона рожденная, которая именно этим и выделяется, да да практически полностью на 100% без ГМО и графона! Только стиль, только артхаус, только хардкор!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=715820039

Играем мы за простого человека, которого угораздило стать проводником и собирать билеты на колесном речном пароходе где все мертвы, уже интригует - не правда ли?

И по ходу сюжета мы будем узнавать истории различных людей и вспоминать свою (как же я давно уже не видел игр в которых главный герой в начале все забывает).

Геймплейно игра представляет собой симулятор ходьбы и периодически разноображивает геймплей разными задачками, к примеру: собери 5 мелков, сделай алкогольный коктейль и т.д.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=715819474

Игра полностью на английском, причем тут даже есть персонаж говорящий стихами, так что если вы не знаете английского вам придется туго.

О саундтреке не говорю ничего, потому что его практически нет, по крайне мере если вы на заднем фоне поставите классическую музыку - игра нисколько не потеряет, а даже наоборот приобретет.

Проходится игра очень быстро, буквально за 40 минут (спасибо что скоротала время в поезде), но если хотите пробежать ради ачивок, то минут 20 (все таки не хватает кнопки бега).

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=715835812

Сюжет простой, вполне легко додумывается в определенных моментах и именно этим и будет держать вас игра, хотением “додумать” до конца, если можно так выразится.

Обычно короткость игры я указываю как недостаток, но тут отлично сработала идея о том что все хорошее должно иметь конец. Простенько, со вкусом и “я хочу еще” - во многом потому что игра заранее старается быть неприглядной, поэтому любые ее открытия воспринимаются с удовольствием.

+Бесплатная
+Короткая
+Простая

-Графика
-Историй то можно было и побольше сделать.

5 из 10

Кураторская группа http://steamcommunity.com/groups/IKCB

很良心的一款游戏。很有哲学意味。
如果说生活很糟糕，你还会再继续下去吗？当你一无所有的时候，你会如何做选择？当你丧失亲情、友情、爱情或者说事业的时候，你会怎么办呢？我们可以继续活着，或者追随自己所爱之人的脚步。这就算是游戏给出的提问吧，如果说你的人生已经足够糟糕，所有的人都已离你而去，你还会选择活下去吗？或许有些人回想一了百了，追随逝去的爱人脱离尘世的苦恼，也许转世投胎，开启新的人生，但是我想告诉大家一点：要坚强地活下去！也许转世投胎却还是如此结局呢？那便成为了永久的遗憾。先不说选择死亡是否是开始新生，人生本就如此，充满了喜怒哀乐。如果说遇到人生的挑战就选择认输，是不是对不起默默支持着自己的人呢？是不是对不起爱你的人呢？好好的活下去吧，千万不要因为生活一团糟而感到担心，因为当你一无所有的时候，你才能放手一搏，创造新的未来，做全新的自己！所以，各位还得要珍惜生命。

游戏是免费的？简直良心！十分推荐！

22084143.review:
I didn't really want to play this game due to the horror tag in the description but.. it's not a horror game, if anything it's a psychological horror, in the sense of messing with your mind.

It's a short game where you enter a boat to ultimately tie some loose ends, that's not really a spoiler by the way, it becomes obvious the first 3 minutes.

The game is free, with 7 very easily obtainable achievements, so achievement hunters, get in. I got them all in 30 minutes of playing. The story is nice but not very original, still nicely told and it's enjoyable.

You're given 2 choices as to how you want the game to end, so technically it has replayability, but not to a great extent.

It would be nice to see a sequel made[spoiler] (based on the Death ending). [/spoiler]

And again, to the ones that are discouraged by the horror tag, it's not a horror game, there is no jump scares or anything, if anything it is purely psychological horror, trying to mess with your mind, I personally love games like that.

It's a pointless walking simulator that you can download for free, you have nothing to lose, there is 2 kinds of people in this world, people who love [i] seemingly [/i] pointless walking simulator with little to no content, and people who hate them.

8/10. A must play for any alternative-Walking Simulator fanatic(and achievement hunters, you will get all achievements within 30 minutes).

An interesting interactive story in which you play as a man who wakes up in a dock in the middle of the sea, and is soon hired to work on a mysterious ferry boat, where he meets some strange individuals. I can't really tell much more about the story, as that would only spoil it; especially considering that this is a very short game, which you can finish in around 30 minutes.

As I mentioned above, it's more of an interactive story, rather than a game, since you just wander around the boat talking to different people in order to progress the story. Even then, the story is somewhat interesting, and the presentation, although quite simple compared to most modern games, adds a certain something to the atmosphere in the game.

Игра про карабль призрак везущий души умерших. Игра на англиском.  Правда я понимал серез слово - мне хватило. Сюжет - интересный (если перевести все диалоги).

Прохождение: идем за  фигурами (они часто проподают - но указывают направление). 
На карабле говорим с капитаном. На мостике капитана смотрим картину.
Идем в каюты: слева 1 каюта - девочка с билетом, 4карандаша, 2 каюта - медвежонок Теди, напротив (2 каюта справа) - картина на стене. Девочке отдаем медвежонка, взамен получаем билет. Билет отдаем капитану.
Идем вдоль борта слева до конца, заходим за двигатели на полу берем карандаш. Возвращаемся в каюты.
В лифте смотрим 2 картины. поднимаемся на верх в бар. В баре включаем музыку в автомате. Пасажиру наливаем напитки: 2-6, 1-5, 3-4 (если смотреть слева направа). Получаем билет. Отдаем капитану. 
На носу карабля разговариваем с женщиной. Получаем билет. Отдаем капитану.
Спускаемся в лифте вниз - кательная. берем карандаш, слева - картина. Говорим с кочегаром - получаем билет. отдаем капитану. Выходим на берег к маяку. Говрим с женщиной и капитаном. Потом идем в один из порталов! Повторно проходим игру и входим в другой портал.

Игра пройдена. Все достижения наши. Учите английский. Всем удачи.

21006984.review:
This free game took about 35 minutes for two runs to get all the achievements. I'm really glad it wasn't much more than that. There's the slightest foundation of a story here but that's about it. In order to solve the mystery of why you're on the ship of the dead and who you and the other people are, you go on a journey of slowly walking back and forth across the ship while having vague conversations and clicking on stuff. The dialogue system is fiddly and prone to accidentally selecting dialogue options by mistake, but it doesn't actually effect anything gameplay wise when you make these choices. There's really not enough emotion here for this experience to get anywhere past slightly unusual/weird. There's no emotional follow through, especially since we don't know or get to know much about anyone involved. 

You have to play the game twice to get all the achievements, because there is one for each ending. Both endings are exactly the same, its just that by walking through one door instead of another you get different sound effects. I also needed the second run to find all the crayons for another arbitrary achievement, because apparently the first time, one of the six crayons fell out of the universe. You can't run, and navigating the very small playing area is tedious after even a few minutes. As time wasting goes, this is only about half an hour, but I still wouldn't bother.

20999668.review:
[table][tr][td][url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/MentorPixel]Mentor Píxel[/url] – [i]El medio interactivo como entretenimiento intelignte[/i][/td][/tr][/table]

[h1][b]Port of Call – El potencial narrativo frustrado[/b][/h1]

[h1]Una caminata poco inspiradora[/h1]
[b][i]Port of Call[/i][/b] es un juego de exploración en primera persona en el que encarnaremos a un personaje que despierta amnésico en un puerto en el medio del océano. Sin tener recuerdos de quién somos ni de cómo llegamos ahí, nos encontraremos con un hombre de edad avanzada y personalidad cándida que nos ordenará colectar los tickets de los pasajeros que encontraremos en su barco, y bajo esta premisa transcurre su narrativa.

Con una exploración bastante limitada, nos encontraremos a unos pocos personajes con los cuales sostendremos conversaciones con diálogos seleccionables, que si bien las opciones no serán vastamente amplias, sí notaremos que recibiremos respuestas distintivas acorde a nuestras elecciones.

La producción audiovisual quizás no sea la más inmersiva del género ni la que más carezca de fallas, pero es evidente que no intenta simular alguna clase de terror, sino más bien un suspenso ligero que inspira misterio e intriga sobre el trasfondo del [i]status quo[/i] de los personajes, y es esta, precisamente, la debilidad del título.

[h1]Un potencial castrado[/h1]
Debido a que la durabilidad del juego es muy reducida, no nos veremos tan involucrados con los personajes como para interesarnos genuinamente en ellos, aspecto que podría afectar negativamente nuestra impresión cuando habremos llegado al clímax de la historia. No obstante, [b][i]Port of Call[/i][/b] espera que el giro argumental al final de la narración nos marque de alguna manera con un mensaje significativo sobre las relaciones personales y nuestra percepción de la vida, y a ciencia cierta, lo logra, muy a pesar de que el argumento del protagonista con amnesia pudiera ser cliché. Cabe notar, no obstante, que el desenlace de este relato nos dejará una moraleja que no pudiera ser contado con un enfoque distinto.

El juego no durará más de una hora así seamos minuciosos con el entorno, y es lamentable que el concepto que brinda este título no pueda ser explotado con una longevidad que permita dar paso a que el jugador se comprometa emocionalmente con su ficción. Probablemente la respuesta a esta disyuntiva es inherente a su comercialización, puesto que el juego es gratis, y como un proyecto independiente sin fines de lucro, cualquier crítica no pudiera ser más de allá de unos pocos aplausos o un pulgar arriba a los desarrolladores, quizás no por su ejecución, sino por su interesante concepto.

El asunto es que de haberse diseñado con una mayor longevidad y un desarrollo más comprometedor y complejo de los personajes, [b][i]Port of Call[/i][/b] pudiese haber tenido el potencial de causar un verdadero impacto en el jugador. Sin embargo, el concepto que ofrece como medio narrativo es lo suficientemente sólido como para ser valorado por sí solo. Quizás le valga la pena probarlo a quienes estén interesados en una narración interactiva corta con un giro argumental un tanto existencialista.

20668722.review:
[h1]Билет на тот свет[/h1]
PoC - короткий депрессивно-мистический рассказ о том, как вы, проснувшись на пристани, вскоре попадаете на корабль, где всё довольно загадочно уже с первых же секунд.
Чтобы не спойлерить скажем так - при понимании английского вы сможете найти эту "часть жизни" довольно привлекательно изображенной.

[h1]Почему бы и да:[/h1]
+ Красивое стилистическое исполнение и атмосфера
+ Депрессивность, загадочность и мистичность. Не смотря на то, что все ответы вы получаете на блюдичке ближе к концу, некоторая нотка непонимания происходящего остается на протяжении всего исследовательского процесса. Даже при том, что об основной теме вы догадаетесь уже через 5-10 минут.
+ Несколько легких музыкальных треков, приукрашивающих обстановку
+ Крайне простые достижения, легкие 100% и +1 идеальная игра
+ Окружение интерактивно. Хоть это и не нужно, я нахожу это огромным плюсом, что можно практически подергать и потыкать чуть ли не каждый объект на корабле
+ Игра со всеми потрошками займет у вас не более 1 часа

Минусов не вижу. Разве что могут быть проблемы на совсем слабом железе (т.к. переключения настроек графики не дают практического эффекта).

[h1]8.5\10[/h1]
Стоит уделить время как любителям интерактивных меланхоличных рассказов, так и ачив-хантерам.

20386325.review:
Port Of Call, um jogo bem simples mas que nasceu ganhando muito! Ele foi o vencedor da feira de games para colégios de jogos, ou algo do genero, na E3 de 2014! Aí explica o gráfico tão bizarro quanto!

Jogo tem umas músicas legais, a trilha sonora não é 100%, pois jogamos a maior parte dele sem se quer tocar uma única música, porém as que ouvimos, sáo boas.

A jogabilidade bem básica, andamos para todos os 4 lados (frente, direita, atrás, e esquerda), e interagimos com a tecla 'E' ou com o mouse, no qual também é responsável pelo movimento da visão do personagem.

Tem que ter uma base no inglês, pois o game está todo nesta língua.

Porém, em termos de física, o jogo foi bem maneiro, permetindo interagir com vários objetos não fixos do cenário, e suas físicas (tirando os que estavam flutuando, que faz parte do jogo, feito de propositalmente), são boas...
No meu caso, eu tirei TODOS os livros das estandes durante o gameplay! xD

Agora o que você fica surpreso, é pela a história que este game possui, eu imaginei que não seria tão profundo e emocionante a história, mas você sente ele, não recomendo para os fracos de coração (brincadeira), no começo não se entende abacaxi nem um do que está a fazer, mas depois que começamos as tarefas e exploração no barco, cada pedaço desse enredo, vai te prendendo, e você fica curioso para saber o final, pois até essa altura, vocè já está montando ele na sua cabeça, de tão simples que é, porém tão interessante que ficou!

Recomendado! Realmente, não podemos julgar o livro pela capa não é mesmo?!

DICA: Leia com atenção as conquistas da Steam, e não se esqueçam delas!

20343475.review:
Port of Call’s central conceit is simple to figure out whether or not you’ve ever read Greek mythology. In fact, the trailer essentially spoils the first “mystery” - i.e., what is the boat and why has it lured you in. The second but central question is answered by piecing together a narrative based on conversations with other passengers.

You begin on a small port surrounded by ocean with a lighthouse barely visible in the distance. You encounter a transient woman followed by a ferryman who hires you for an unexplained job. The ferryman himself is lithe, jovial, and snarky all at once. His simple instructions are to retrieve a passenger’s ticket. His simple job has the effect of granting some order to the chaos of the opening scene. It’s a wonderful trick, as it provides guidance and normalcy at a junction in the game where the player doesn’t know anything. The captain’s presence is avuncular and almost calming.

The game’s creepiness in general is offset by its jaunty atmosphere. The graphics consist of clean lines and deep, opaque hues. The color scheme is dark, but the presentation itself isn’t melancholy. The ship is physically small but has a presence that’s difficult to explain. Some games, films, and books burst with detail and eye candy but fail to capture a milieu, or a sense of place. In Port of Call, which can be completed in maybe ten to fifteen minutes, I found myself exploring what little space there was to observe all of the detail. The ship was clearly crafted with care and meticulousness rather than caprice. Thus, it has a presence that balances amiability and angst.

While I believe the first two thirds of the game captures what Poe calls the “unity of effect,” or the interplay of an artwork’s elements contributing to a single effect, the last third is flawed. The last third involves beating the player over the head with shameless exposition. The first two thirds allows the player to stitch the story together without narratorial intrusion. The last third is overt and ruins the fastidiously crafted effect.

However, despite the flawed ending, Port of Call is worth playing for what it achieves. Like other similar titles, such as the magnificent Thirty Flights of Loving and free prequel Gravity Bone, Port of Call opens new possibilities for video games as art.

20146099.review:
在东方神话里，人死后要经过一道奈何桥，桥上要喝下一杯孟婆汤，那是以为名叫孟婆的老人用一生的感悟熬下的汤，喝下之后可以让人忘记生前一切快乐与哀愁，像个初生婴儿一样抛下一切负担走向来生；而西方也有一个摆渡人，通过收船票的方式让死者摆脱生前的一切纠葛，带着纯净的灵魂走向彼岸。

不管你生前多么伟大，或者多么卑微，死后同样会获得这样一个让你检视自己一生的机会。在这个过程中有的人抛下了心结，干干净净地走向了解脱；有的人最终承受不住内心的拷问，在最后的选择中彻底迷失。每个人一生中都有可能犯下一些过错，但这并不重要，重要的是你能不能面对自己的内心。

这款游戏其实篇幅还是很有限的，如果是一个正规的、成熟完善的作品的话，流程不会只有这么短；人物不会只有这么少；线索不会这么单一；渡船的每一层都可以刻画成心灵的每一个不同的侧面，做得再虚化一些；音乐和语音也可以更佳充分一些。好在作者自己也深知这款游戏的不成熟，所以有意做成了一道免费的人生小甜点。作为免费游戏的话，确实上面的一切也就没什么可抱怨的了——只要花费45分钟的时间，就能给自己带来略略一些日常生活中体会的感悟，这样的免费游戏已经可说完美。

游戏本身流程很短，就一节课的时间，在一种莫名的心灵震动之余也收获了一些人生感悟：
1. 无论你的人生有多么痛苦悲惨、有多么卑微不堪令人绝望，死后都可以获得一个公平审视自身的机会
2. 人一生中很可能会犯下各种过错，很多时候对错本身并不重要，重要的是能否通过自己内心的审问
3. 无论在生前还是死后，人都总会需要做出各种选择，而选择就意味着得到一些的同时又失去领一些重要的东西。而无论在生前还是死后，很多东西错过了就是错过了，再也无法挽回了。所以，请珍惜现在拥有的一切，并重视每一次选择。

+1 讲了一个很短但能够触动人心的小故事
+1 免费游戏中少有的能让人获得一些感触的作品
+1 出场人数就四五个，当时每一个塑造的都让人印象深刻，特别是那个面冷心热的傲娇摆渡船长。
+1 45分钟可全成就
-0.5 无中文，好在英文不算难
-0.5 内容有限，结构太简单，虽然对免费游戏来说不能要求太多

总评：8  给疲倦的人生来一道免费小甜点

Overall, I'd say it's an interesting story idea, but very short, and gameplay is a little meh. But it's an alright thing to waste a half an hour on for free. Especially if you're into visual novels and/or walking simulators.

20047493.review: Con i saldi natalizi di Steam che impennano e i portafogli che si svuotano, cadere al fascino di un buon free-to-play è molto degno di me, e ormai lo dico con un certo compiacimento. Port of Call non è stranamente definito da nessuno uno "walking simulator", e questo fa riflettere molto su questo genere. Sebbene Dear Esther e Gone Home siano espliciti riferimenti del team di sviluppo (cercate "Gallaga: UT student team builds spooky game in just one semester" per trovare la mia fonte), forse la narrativa troppo esplicitamente rivelata, forse le pochissime (ma pur presenti) sequenze interattive presenti e necessarie per progredire allontanano Port of Call dalla suddetta etichetta per avvicinarla a quella di "avventura". Port of Call è stato costruito da zero in un semestre universitario da un team di sei studenti afferenti a corsi diversi della University of Texas di Austin: l'estrema competenza nei vari settori dei cocreatori (programmazione, writing, modelling...) giustifica un prodotto di qualità davvero notevole; i tempi ristretti (finalizzati a presentare il gioco a un concorso universitario nell'ambito dell'E3) un prodotto per certi aspetti poco rifinito. Rimestando nel calderone dell'immaginario dell'aldilà e delle transizioni dell'anima, i nostri sei studenti texani ci mettono davanti a un impacciato Caronte e a un cast di personaggi ben caratterizzati, graficamente ammiccanti verso la Città incantata di Miyazaki, i Korogu di Wind Waker e il cell shading di Okami. La visuale in prima persona è usata sapientemente per creare incertezza sull'entità del protagonista (spoiler di qui in avanti), che dovrà letteralmente decidere da solo se il suo io (e di conseguenza il suo corpo) sia morto o meno. Assai raffinata è la scelta di raffigurare la parte oscura dell'io come un fuochista, che con il carbone dell'anima alimenta il fuoco della condizione ultraterrena a cui il protagonista ha relegato i suoi cari. La riunificazione della coscienza può portare all'autoassoluzione, ma non a capovolgere la sabbia nella clessidra: la soluzione ultima è una questione di etica personale, dove comunque sia non esistono lieto fini su una nave al tramonto. La "frettolosità" di Port of Call si percepisce soprattutto sull'ambigua introduzione del tema del suicidio, mai totalmente "srotolato": l'intelaiatura della trama risulta così forse un po' troppo esile, non riempiendosi neanche di spinta esegetica soggettiva dal momento in cui non viene data (ovviamente) sufficiente carne al fuoco per le speculazioni. I finali, che altrove vedo essere stati di ampio dibattito, peccano in un utilizzo veramente mediocre dei mezzi audiovisivi disponibili. E' comprensibile infatti l'impossibilità di aggiungere delle vere e proprie sequenze animate, ma il fonosimbolismo e le semplici scelte coloristiche, se usate con maggiore accortezza, avrebbero veramente aggiunto qualcosa al valore finale del prodotto, senza considerare che il completamento del gioco può essere considerato tale solo dopo due playthrough. In definitiva, anche se queste frasi nascondono sempre dietro a un augurio una maledizione, spero che il team in questione non consideri episodica la loro comparsa sullo scenario videoludico e possa, con calma, progettare qualcosa di stile simile ma "in grande". Resta solo da scegliere la porta giusta.

19553547.review:
This review will be incredibly short as I don't want to spoil anything about the game cause it is incredibly short, so let's get started.

Port of Call cast you as a man who doesn't remember anything. You find yourself about to board a ferry boat and it's up to you to find out what happened to you and why are you there.

The story is a really good tale and it grips you to finish this game. 

It has a really creepy atmosphere as the ferry itself is shrouded in mystery as you try to piece together the story. 

The game itself could be regarded as a walking simulator as there is not much you can do, just walk around and 
examine things around you.

The game took me 20 minutes to finish, but there are multiple endings so you can see the different outcomes.

Overall there's not much I can say about Port of Call. It's a great title and is definitely worth your time and not to mention it's also free.

Final Rating:
8/10 - Play it

19357589.review:
Don't pay the ferryman...

Port of Call – when completing this game, certainly is a fitting title. Also please do not get this mixed up with the naval / simulation game Ports of Call (note the plural ‘Ports’). This game is totally free in Steam that tells the story of you, on a ferry boat, not knowing how you got there in the first place. Plays upon the narrative / walking simulator theme however it’s a little more than simply looking at the scene and moving on to the next. The backdrop story, whilst not original however still interesting enough to play through until the end.

The game’s visuals all renders in cell shading and nicely done. However there are times where the frame rate drops all of a sudden when more items suddenly appear on the screen. However, because the game’s pace, this does not deter the gameplay at all. The controls are extremely simple to learn as it plays along with ‘traditional’ adventure games without inventory management. Furthermore there’s almost no puzzles to solve however, like I have mentioned before, it plays along with telling the story instead of puzzle solving. The musical scores, whilst all short in nature, do produce a meticulous, mournful tone; similar to those ambience scores from the Stalker series.

Without inventory management, this may be the bane of playing any adventure games however due to its short length (about 30 mins) and being free, you really cannot argue about this. Normally I will dismiss the idea of amnesia stories as, for me, they portray lazy story writing falsely perpetrating the mystery behind the main protagonist, I’m happy to dismiss it this time. Also, the project (game) was part of the finalist at E3 2014 from the team of students from UT Austin’s Game and Mobile Media Applications (GAMMA) program, I hope the team continues on developing more games as I was impressed with this one.

8 / 10

Let me start by saying that when I first saw this, I didn't want to play it due to the horror tag and the trailer. When I saw that it had achievements for a free game, I thought to give it a shot (since it was short). I was honestly ready to write a negative review right off the bat. I was wrong.

Though this game is short (and with a rather cliche story), it is still a well-told story that is to be enjoyed. To ease the fears of those who dread horror games, this game is very tame. Creepy...yet tame. No screamers. No gore. Only a feeling of discomfort in your own mind, yet not terrifyingly bad. Just creepy enough to catch your attention.

Pros:
Free
Achievements
A nice tale to be told
A nice cast of interesting characters

Cons:
Story can be a little overtold. ()
A little too short.


It is also another "choose your own ending" game, but it's based on personal preference after everything you've experienced. Me? I'll admit that when it came to life or death, I chose death. (Though I'd normally choose life, circumstances led me to believe life would be more painful)

If this was longer and if more work went into it, I could see this thing becoming something great. I wish there was an epilogue or sequel for those taking the "Death Door".
It's worth to play this game for 3 reasons:
1. It's 100% free.
2. Very easy to collects 100% of achievements, which took me not even an hour.
3. And most important, it's quite nice adventure game.
It's really good way to spend half an hour of your spare time. Don't expect anything revolutionary, it's only budget indie game. A game which tells you nice story. And this story is something worth to read. Just don't skip the dialogues.
Also it's worth to make a decision in final stage.

VERDICT:
Yes, it's worth to give it a chance, and c'mon, it's free.This is probably the shortest game I every played... which is fine. Took me about 20-25 minutes to play it. And another 10 Minutes to complete the rest of the achievements I was missing.

Pro:
+ Free to Play
+ nice and simple graphic
+ simple controls
+ easy to 100%

Con:
- very short 

If you can spare half an hour and are into adventure, explore games you should definitively try this. You board the ferry to learn about your past, and in the end you choose your final outcome. 

The game is very short taking no longer than 15-30 min. What you do learn of your character is actually quite tragic in some ways and does make you consider the end you choose. And given that there are two endings, it means this game has more endings than Mass Effect. I did repeat the game to "see" both endings. 

It's worth playing if you like moody dark wispy ghosts everywhere and add a slight tinge of depression to your day.

18592351.review:
This one will be pretty brief; you’ve been warned. Port of Call is an indie exploration horror game from Underdog Game. Let’s get rocking.

The Good

The number one draw to this game is that it is free. You pay literally nothing. The only thing this game will cost you is some of your time. Admittedly, not very much, but still, there it is.

I quite liked the art style of the game. It wasn’t the greatest by any stretch of the imagination, but it went well with the overall feel of the game.

The story was simple and, honestly, I enjoyed it quite a bit.

Port of Call offers players an interesting take on the afterlife.

The Bad

For a free game, there was nothing that I encountered that I’d feel good about putting into this category.

The Meh

I’m going to stick to my guns as to the above statement in the “Bad” section. I’ve got nothing bad to say about Port of Call.

Verdict: Yea

You’ve got virtually nothing to lose by getting PoC from the Steam Store and taking it for a playthrough. Two playthroughs will get you all seven achievements and my first play through was just shy of thirty minutes. The game itself is a fun game and it is completely free. If you’re looking for a lightly spooky game, look no further. As always, thanks for reading.

18531308.review: I hate giving a negative review to a free game, especially one that looks like a decent amount of thought and effort went into it, but i gotta be honest. This is a short walking sim in the vein of Gone Home, where you discover more about who you are and your place in the world as you progress through the game. The graphics are sort of a stylized, cell-shaded thing, which is an interesting choice for the "creepy" vibe that permeates the experience. The music and sound effects are fairly neat too. Where it falls down, for me, is the way in which the story is revealed. The concept is pretty cool and it has a lot of potential, but the dialog was a bit too on-the-nose. It would have benefited from leaving things more enigmatic and letting the player fill in the gaps. As it is, the turning point felt forced to me, which undermines what i suppose was meant to be an emotional climax. Worth a look since it's free, but don't expect too much.

18251976.review:
A traveller with no memory on a journey to an unknown land, you must board a strange ship and follow the guidance of a weary captain to learn the secrets of your past, and make the ultimate decision along the way.

Port of Call is a very brief but interesting experiment in interactive storytelling that endeavors to question the consequences of our actions on the world and people around us. You'll tread the decks of a bizarre, otherworldly ship and interact with its equally odd passengers in a minimalist, cel-shaded world. As sparse as the presentation may be, there's enough style and intrigue and symbolism to hold the player's attention and push them further to delve into the mystery of who you are and why you are there.

I really like when games try something a little different like this and mix things up, not only with content, but with themes and subject matters as is the case here. It's short, it's free, and it's a pleasant, thoughtful experience that deserves the brief moment of your time to explore something just a little bit different.

18118115.review:
Port of Call is a well told, albiet short story.

The gameplay is in the same vein as Gone Home or Dear Esther, choosing to focus entirely on the narrative with minimal player interactions. The player starts off on a pier, with nothing but the light and silhouette of a distant lighthouse breaking the monotony of a vast ocean. After inspecting a strange figure standing at the other end of the pier a tall man apears, claiming that you're late and ushering the player on to his ship - which has now just appeared. On the ship the captain tells the player to collect tickets from ther other passengers. From there the player talks to each passenger. learns who they are, why they are on the ship and what the player has to do with any of this.

There's not much to be said besides that to be honest, the game is very short and describing the story anymore would spoil it. The player talks to each passenger, is given a few choices on dialogue and a simple task to complete, usually picking up an item and returning it to the passenger. Besides that there isn't anything else to the gameplay.

Graphically the game is quite nice, with everything presented in a somewhat cel-shaded style. It's symplistic but it works and all the assets fit together with out anything looking out of place. The sound is much the same, each character has a sound cue that plays when they talk to give them a little more personality and what music there is helps the mood.

Ultimately though, whether or not you'll enjoy the game depends on how much you enjoy the story. As mentioned before it's very short and while there are different responses to the different dialogue choices as well as two different endings, the whole game can be completed in a single sitting. There are acheivement but they don't really add to the game and feel a little tacked on at the end.

Personally, I enjoyed the game. It's a nice short story with a fitting mood and a neat style.

18054579.review:
You wake up on a dock. You board a strange boat. You have to meet people to retrieve their tickets to satisfy the captain. But everything is strange: between the passengers with masks, items floating in the air and the shadows, you're asking yourself if you're in the realm of Death or it's just a dream...

Port of Call is a small adventure game, in a cartoonish style, where you're trying to find who you are and why you need to meet these passengers. Listening to their stories is also interesting because they hold the key to your identity.

The soundtrack is good, like the graphics that are so reassuring and freakening at the same time: while it's not a dark game, when you see floating stuffs, a huge toy sheet and shadows, you're asking yourself what's happening. You understand quickly that you're maybe dead but then, why are you collecting tickets? Shouldn't you be a simple passenger?

Anyway, there are no puzzles there: apart speaking, finding a teddy bear and mixing drinks, you're just confronted to a poor gameplay. Yet, the dialogues here are important if you want to understand the story and find answers. The quest for the pencils and the paintings is also a nice bonus, though that for the paintings, it's very easy.

The main problem of the game is the fact that you have an hard time to find a menu, you have to press Escape to make it appear and to quit properly the game. The screen title lacks options.

But there is another problem with the game that will bother AZERTY users. The game is set with WASD keys, without ZQSD alternative or arrows. While the fix for comfort is to move the mouse and to keep pressing on W, as it's not natural  to press the W instead of the Z, once you're releasing the key, you have some seconds to remind yourself, that no, the key you're so used to press isn't the same.

Other than that, I enjoyed the experience. And it's free with achievements!

18010811.review:
You wake up on a small pier facing murky waters with no recollection of who you are, you're soon approached by a ferryman and board his ship only to find out things are not as real as they seem.
A very short and simple game with a great narrative dealing with death, choices and consequences Port of Call does suffer from overly low production values but thankfully they don't detract too much from its excellent story.

[b]PROS:[/b]

-eerie, creepy atmosphere 

-great story 

-interesting, cryptic dialogue slowly lets you realize what's happened to you

-the music is pretty good

[b]CONS:[/b]

-while I can forgive the simple graphics I have to mention two bad elements to them: firstly most objects have a very thick black outline as a sort of faux cell shading, it doesn't really work and looks bad while also being sometimes drawn as you move making it look very unrealistic. The second problem is the quite huge amount of clipping the character models have with arms passing through themselves and pieces of skin coming out of clothes.

-very short, expect around 20 minutes to complete

-apart from a dual choice at the ending the game is very linear and has no replay value once you're done

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=517449970

Port of Call is basically a slightly interactive story, you move around the ship, do a few simple tasks, have conversations with people you meet (sometimes choosing between a few different questions) and that's that: its story is truly great though and makes the game a worthwhile experience. I cannot spoil anything but while starting a bit slow and murky you'll eventually hit a twist that explains everything and have to face a decision that truly has some emotional strings attached to it.

The game is an easy recommendation to anyone wanting to experience a good story, it made me wish the devs had an higher budget to truly flesh it out and make a complete game out of it: even as things stand you'd play it at least once and, to be honest, a second playthrough to see the other ending while reading again through conversations knowing what truly happened is also is totally worth it.

17993041.review:
For the Younger Crowd

I've been playing games a long time, and while the younger crowd might enjoy their experience it was nothing new to me.  The premise is nothing I haven't seen before and while the explanation for the shadows is good, it's not like the game brings anything fresh.  

I realize it's an experiment, but for the content presented there needs to be more than what's given.  This is the sort of thing that would be better suited to a different format because the simple graphics fail to make it all that imersive.  Nobody seems to mind me bouncing books or other items off them, I could see where the story was going after meeting the little old man (and confirmed by the time I met the little girl) that there was really no surprises for me.

I'd recommend a different engine.  The first person view just doesn't work for the amount of abstraction the game clearly wants to capture.  The story is far too short, too linear, and too straightforward.  The concept isn't bad but it needs a different presentation -- otherwise it's just another walking around sim.

17960557.review:
Os desenvolvedores de Port of Call sabiam que tinham em mãos um título anti-comercial por definição: curto, com pouca jogabilidade, com gráficos sui generis, e um tema que não costuma atrair audiência. Sabiamente, escolheram distribuir o jogo gratuitamente no Steam. Porque o inverso de comercial é Arte em estado puro e conciliar as duas esferas não é tarefa das mais fáceis.

A atmosfera de Port of Call é onírica. Mas não a de um sonho bom que você gostaria de lembrar no dia seguinte, mas de algo opressor, um terror noturno que se deita sobre o seu peito com perguntas sombrias e respostas ainda piores. Enquanto você tenta reconstruir suas memórias e porque está nesse estranho barco com passageiros mascarados, vai revelando uma história de dor profunda. Não é um jogo bonito para a alma, ainda que o final possa trazer algum alento.

Embora eu tenha colocado o marcador de Adventure, o título se assemelha mais aos infames "walking simulators", uma vez que não há enigmas para resolver e não tenho certeza se suas respostas nos diálogos levam a resultados diferentes. A louvável exceção está na cena do bar. Olhando em retrospecto, você entende porque você tinha que fazer o que fez, se tornando o agente da situação. É uma boa sacada em um jogo sucinto que se completa em meia hora.

Port of Call é um jogo para ser enfrentado em um dia cinza. Um conto gótico que se levanta das brumas do século XIX, azeda o leite e retorna para o oblívio.

Originalmente publicado em: http://blog.retinadesgastada.com.br/2015/09/jogando-port-of-call.html

17945770.review:
For a proper judgment I have to ignore it's a free game and just evaluate whether it's worth playing. That's why I gave it a thumbs down.

Playing a free low-skill tech demo still occupies your time, and unless you consider that worthless, you can skip Port of Call without having to worry that you miss anything.

This game proves nothing more that the dev has very basic technical game-making skills. The story writing and such is slightly below OK. The story is like a copy of a witty story with surprise twists and then making it fully predictable, removing anything special and appealing from it, so it's bascially totally unspectacular. Also, the dialogues, while occasionally providing choices, not only have no effect on the progress of events, but often don't even result in different responses. This was especially bad towards the end, when the resolution forces its course even if your dialogue choices go totally against it, and that was like the seal of truth on what I perceived before.

There are achievements for doing stuff of no consequence or even not making sense. You collect crayons that are lying around. Why? Why should you pick them up? You have no need for them, no incentive to pick them up.

Even so much as different text colors for you and others was too much to ask. Your text is placed slightly lower than NPC text, that's all.

I don't know, maybe some people actually find this entertaining (especially if you have never experienced remarkable writing), but generally a game published on Steam should be focused on the player, not the developer. This is like: "Look, I can make a game with kind of a story. Please take half an hour to admire that. I offer it for free, so you cannot complain no matter what."

I feel like I watched a commercial. Or participated in a beta-testing run.

I recently played "the static speaks my name" and I found that a tiny bit better due to how it at least made me ponder a little on what message it might be trying to convey.

17941252.review: Un petit jeu très intéressant. Les graphismes sont aux antipodes d'un Witcher III ou d'un Skyrim. Réalisé (sans doute mais sans certitude) avec Unity, le jeu est une exploration minimaliste où l'on découvre quelques informations sur le personnage que l'on incarne. L'intérêt, comme beaucoup de jeu indépendant, réside dans le concept et l'histoire. Les énigmes sont très simples et l'exploration réduite et le jeu est résolu en un petit quart d'heure (il n'y a d'ailleurs pas de système de sauvegarde). Il y a néanmoins du travail derrière cette apparence minimale et l'ambiance sonore et le travail sur la musique donnent une sensation agréable, nostalgique. Deux fins sont proposées... ce qui implique de jouer deux fois le jeu. Cela reste intéressant à rejouer car cela permet des variations dans les dialogues. En plus, c'est gratuit ;-) Pourquoi se priver d'un petit moment calme, en suspension dans un autre univers... ?

17925825.review:
[b]A light, thirty-minute-long mystery game regarding your journey to the afterlife,[/b] 
[spoiler]or to revival...[/spoiler] [b]and reflection on past life choices.[/b]

Although it does touch on darker subjects such as death and alcoholism, I'd hardly call this a horror game as it's been tagged. No jumpscares, no chase-scenes, no blood or gore. It's pretty tame, although some people might find the atmosphere a bit creepy.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] It's mostly just walking around and talking to people. You'll pick up an item now and then.

[b]Story:[/b] The story is predictable and not exactly a mind-blower, but it is decently satisfying to play through. 

[b]Dialogue:[/b] The writing is pretty well done, no spelling or grammatical errors that I noticed. 

[b]Disclaimer:[/b] Not a very polished game, I clipped through several structures. And It doesn't have a save feature, so if you quit or crash the game you'll have to start all over again, which is quite annoying. (It crashed on me while trying to use Alt+Tab.) Also, if you want all the achievements you'll have to play the game twice.

Overall it's not fantastic, but there are certainly worse ways of spending thirty minutes. 
Short, sweet, and free. Give it a go.

This is a very short, but interesting little game. You wake up at a pier, not knowing who or where you are. The old man invites you to enter his boat, and then an original story unfolds. Which proved necessary in order to get real enjoyment, since neither the graphics nor the audio is up to the level of the story. At the end the game left me in disarry for a moment, since it is rather grim and unsettling.

But since this is a free game, there's no reason not to recommend it. Furthermore, it comes with seven achievements which can be unlocked easily, so for anyone looking for 100% games this is a must. Do play it twice: the story made much more sense to me on my second playthrough, and the game is really short.

[b]Recommend to everyone interested in something slightly different[/b]

17837991.review:
"Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication." - Leonardo Di Vinci

Port Of Call is more of an interactive short story than a game.
Do not go playing this expecting some grand multiple choice point and click.
This game is humble, it does not pretend to be anything more than what it is.

The graphics are simplistic, cell-shaded and otherworldly.
The story itself is quite straightforward but nonetheless manages to be sad, character-driven and thought provoking.
The world is small in terms of what you can explore, but from the perspective of the narrative has much potential were this game to ever be expanded upon.

All in all I think it's fair to call this game a piece of art.
It may be abstract, but it is art nonetheless.
I have seen many games attempt to be art and fail, but this game succeeds.
Whether that is what it sets out to be is irrelivent.

Juego interesante, subes a un barco y el capitán te dice que debes encontrar los tickets de los pasajeros.

Puede decirse que es exploración y ambiente, hay que coger varias cosas para sacarse los logros: los tickets, que los sueltan los pasajeros cuando terminas con ellos; los lápices, todos en las habitaciones, uno por detrás del barco (tras las aspas) y en la caldera; y los cuadros, en las habitaciones, en el bar y en la caldera.
